metadata.title: Osteoarthritis  Occupational Therapy •Cardiorespiratory function and endurance : Assess aerobic activity tolerance, endurance for functional activities. Patients who have OA demonstrate decreased aerobic capacity.(11)Note if the patient is easily fatigued or reports shortness of breath with activities. Assess pulse bilaterally and note any abnormalities •Ergonomics/body mechanics : Assess patient’s posture and technique used for functional activities; observe compensatory techniques and the amount of force used on joints •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.): Assess patient’s functional mobility •Gait/locomotion: Assess for antalgic gait or excessive compensatory mechanisms •Joint integrity and mobility : Assess integrity, stability, mobility, and deformity of the involved joints. Joint hypomobility and tenderness/pain are commonly associated with OA. Note crepitus, swelling, heat, and/or redness –Note the presence of joint deformity of the hand -Heberden’s nodes of the DIP joints -Bouchard’s nodes of the PIP joints -Thumb CMC instability/subluxation    •Motor function (motor control/tone/learning): Assess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities and hands, as well as coordination; describe the quality of movement –Observe manual dexterity: serial opposition or rapidly touching each finger to thumb in succession –Use standardized assessments whenever possible –Note if any tremor or ataxia •Muscle strength : Perform manual muscle testing (MMT) for bilateral extremities, noting any asymmetry or abnormality. Patients with OA often have diminished strength(14) –Test hand strength through MMT, Jamar dynamometer for grip strength, pinch meters for pinch strength –Do not perform MMT on muscles with contractures, abnormal tone, or coordination impairment •Observation/inspection/palpation  (including skin assessment): Observe for any deformities, nodes, ligament laxity, or swelling of individual joints.(10) Inspect joints for redness, swelling, pain, subluxation or dislocation, crepitus, and tendon rupture. Common deformities include CMC subluxation, Heberden’s nodes, and Bouchard’s nodes –Palpate joints to assess for ligament laxity, deformity, or swelling(10) –Document presence of any skin breakdown, including decubitus ulcers and open wounds, especially if the patient wears splints or braces •Perception (e.g., visual field, spatial relations) –Ocularmotor screening includes tracking through all planes, visual accommodation, and clarity of vision -Document complaints of double vision, optic pain, or visual field cuts -Document use of eye patching and/or corrective lenses –Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  is appropriate if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during evaluation –For additional information on assessment and treatment of patients with visual impairments, see  Clinical Review…Visual Dysfunction: Occupational Therapy ; CINAHL Topic IDNumber: T708963 •Posture : Assess patient’s posture in standing as well as during functional activities. Note the use of compensatory techniques and the amount of force that is placed on a joint during functional activities •Range of motion : Assess bilateral passive and active ROM. ROM often is diminished in patients with moderate to severe OA (e.g., hip extension, internal rotation, abduction, external rotation, adduction, and flexion might be diminished in patients with hip OA)(14) –Document presence of contractures –Document pain with any active or passive movement •Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –FIM – observation of eating; grooming; bathing; dressing upper extremity; dressing lower extremity; bowel management; bladder management; transfers to bed, chair, and wheelchair; transfer to tub, toilet, and shower; and walking or wheelchair propulsion and stair climbing, each rated on a 7-point  scale on amount of assistance needed(5) –Klein-Bell  Activities of Daily Living Scale—observation of 6 areas of ADLs: mobility, emergency communication, dressing, elimination, bathing/hygiene, and eating, rated able to perform, unable to perform, or not applicable(10) –Document IADLs functioning such as housework, meal preparation, and driving •Sensory testing : Assess bilateral sensation for light-touch,  sharp/dull, 2-point  discrimination, temperature, pressure, proprioception, and vibration •Special tests specific to diagnosis –Arthritis Hand Function Test: standardized measurement of the hand for adults with OA(10) –Australian/Canadian Osteoarthritis Hand Index (AUSCAN): assessment of pain, stiffness, and physical disability of persons with OA of the hands(13) –Arthritis Impact Measurement Scales (AIMS): assessment consisting of 12 areas that measure QOL of persons with arthritis(13) –Hip Disability and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS): assessment of patients’ view about their hip and related functioning(35) –Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS): assessment of patients’ view about their knee and related functioning(36)    Assessment/Plan of Care
anatomical location body part affected: Musculoskeletal system, primarily the cartilage and subchondral bone in any joint in the body. The most common joints affected are hips, knees, spine, distal interphalangeal joints, trapeziometacarpal joint, and first metatarsophalangeal joint(1)
description: Osteoarthritis (OA) has been found to be the leading cause of disability in those over 65 years of age.(2) OA is a progressive loss of joint cartilage leading to changes in subchondral bone and changes at joint margins. OA is no longer considered a condition of wear and tear associated with aging. Most patients with symptomatic OA experience an inflammatory component. Over the past 10 years new knowledge on cartilage has led to a change in the approach to treatment of OA(1)

Primary osteoarthritis: idiopathic in etiology,(2) most commonly found in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints of the fingers, the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint of the thumb, the metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint of the big toe, the hip, the knee, and the cervical and lumbar spine(21)

Secondary osteoarthritis might occur in any joint as the result of articular injury. The injury might be acute, as in a fracture, or chronic such as in overuse, metabolic disease, or neurologic disorders(21)

For more detailed information on osteoarthritis, see  Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis, Cervical  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708512;  Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis/ Osteoarthrosis: Carpometacarpal Joint of Thumb  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708514;  Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis, Hip  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708732; and  Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis, Knee (Nonoperative Management)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708412

No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified –Presentation/signs and symptoms of OA vary, but can include -joint pain, swelling, and crepitus(4,5) -transient stiffness after immobility that lessens 10–15  minutes after movement of the joint(2) -changes in joint alignment: genuvarus (bow-legged)  or genuvalgus (knock-kneed) -Bouchard’s nodes: bony enlargement on the PIP joints of the hand(4) -Heberden’s nodes: bony enlargement on the DIP joints of the hand(4) -CMC joint instability is a core problem with thumb OA(22) -muscle weakness and/or muscle atrophy associated with affected joint(2) -decreased ROM(5) -decreased coordination(5) -poor posture(5) -antalgic gait(5) -decreased functional mobility and performance of ADLs Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Caution should be exercised regarding the amount of resistance prescribed for exercise programs; increased resistive exercises can cause increased inflammation at the joints(7)
Scan all joints (knees, shoulders, wrist, and hands) for generalized OA involvement
Pain should be respected; pain management is an important factor in patient compliance with therapy programs(8)
Verbal and numerical rating scales best quantify pain in older adults(23)
Postpone exam if patient exhibits symptoms of acute flare-up  with atypical severe joint pain or suspicion of fracture

causes: Primary osteoarthritis: Idiopathic and categorized by clinical features (i.e., localized, generalized, erosive)(2)

Secondary osteoarthritis: A sequela to articular injury–Acute or chronic trauma(3)–Inheritable arthropathy(2)–Endocrinopathies(2)–Paget disease(2)–Noninfectious inflammatory arthritis(2)–Overuse of intraarticular steroids(3)–Childhood anatomic abnormalities(2)–Inherited metabolic disorders(2)–Neuropathic, hemophilic, endocrine arthropathy(2)–Gout, calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease(2)–Septic or tuberculous arthritis(2)
pathogenesis typical progression: In the early stages, fissures and microfibrillations occur in the cartilage, leading to erosion of joint cartilage. In advancedcases,(1) the loss of cartilage makes the joint more susceptible to further injury(6)
Weight-bearing  and shearing forces impact the subchondral bone at the periphery of the affected joint, resulting in thedevelopment of osteophytes (spurs) at the joint margins(1,6)
Cartilage or bone fragments are released into the joint, which leads to further cartilage damage and joint space narrowing(6)
Further cartilage damage can occur when cartilage breakdown associated with synovial inflammation leads to the release ofcytokines and enzymes(6)
risk factors: Age: persons over the age of 50 are at increased risk for osteoarthritis(2)
Age: persons over the age of 70 are at greatest risk for hip and knee OA(2)
Repetitive stress on joints from sports or work(2)
Trauma or injury to joint; infection of joint(2)
Sex: women are more likely to develop osteoarthritis than men(2)
Hand OA occurs most often in postmenopausal women(2)
Bone abnormalities, anatomical malalignment, and biomechanical factors such as leg-length  discrepancy andproprioceptive deficits(1,4,6)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document any known injury or trauma, if any. Document when symptoms first began. Document the progression of symptoms since the onset of illness

course of treatment.medical management: Document course of medical treatment received, including any surgical interventions, such as arthroscopic debridement, hemiarthroplasty, total hip/knee/shoulder replacement, or spinal fusion(9,10) Document the use of any splints or braces
course of treatment.medications: Document any medications clinician has prescribed; include patient compliance and stated effectiveness in controlling symptoms Medications Acetaminophen (Tylenol) up to 1,000mg 4 times daily(2,9) Tramadol (Ultram) up to 300mg 3 times daily(1,5) Low-dose  NSAIDs/COX-2  inhibitor, lowest effective dose for the shortest time possible(2,9) Nonacetylated salicylates(1) Intraarticular injections Glucocorticoid injections(9) Hyaluronan(1) Topical Topical NSAIDs (diclofenac gel)(2,9) Topical analgesics(6) (e.g., capsaicin cream [Zostrix])
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed : Usual tests for this condition are the following:
MRI to rule out other pathology
X-ray  films might show narrow, asymmetric joint space, formation of osteophytes, subchondral bone sclerosis, and/or formation of cyst(2)
Joint aspiration to differentiate among inflammatory arthritis, septic arthritis, and osteoarthritis(2)
Radiographs do not always correlate with pain and ADL function in persons with OA. The use of radiographs in the management of knee pain is not recommended(27)
Authors of a study developed predefined clinical questions (PCQs) and found they can predict the severity of knee OA(27)
The PCQs included the presence of pain and the patient’s ability to perform the following ADLS: walking, stair
climbing, getting up from a chair, squatting, and sitting crosslegged.  Each question was rated on a scale of 0-10 with 10 being able to perform the activity without pain
Authors of a study examined the relationship between clinical and radiological diagnosis of knee and hip OA and ADLs in older adults(26)
Radiographs were used to characterize OA as one of five grades, from 0 (no OA) to 4 (severe OA); a score of ≥ 2 indicated the presence of OA
Clinical diagnosis was based on the criteria of the American College of Radiologywhich considermedical history, laboratory tests, and physical examinations
The EuroQOL survey evaluated patients’ ADL abilities
Clinical diagnosis of OA was found to bemore strongly related to the inability to perform ADLs than radiographic diagnosis alone
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., heat modalities soaks, hot showers, hot packs) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and their effectiveness Authors of a meta-analysis  of RCTs found that oral chondroitin is more effective than placebo in decreasing pain and improving function. Glucosamine useto improve stiffness is supported. There are not enough studies evaluating the combination of glucosamine and chondroitin to evaluate effectiveness(28) Authors of an RCT (N = 90) evaluated the effects of aromatherapy massage with lavender essence on ADLs in patients with knee OA. Results suggest that lavender aromatherapy massage could have temporary positive effects on the ability to perform ADLs(29)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Document use of assistive aids such as splints, canes, crutches, or braces.(1) Document if patient participates in a home exercise program.Ask if patient has participated in communitybased  self-management arthritis programs or aquatic therapy

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before symptoms come on or are eased). Do certain activities aggravate symptoms? Does the patient consider exercise helpful for reducing pain and/or improving mobility?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (stiffness, constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present and ask patient to grade pain level)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (am, mid-day, pm, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the need for any supplemental oxygen Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask patient about previous history of OA and any other musculoskeletal disorders/injuries
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, osteoporosis, and orthopedic disorders. Hypertension, heart disease, and OA commonly occur together(12)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing, including fatigue

Determine any repetitive behaviors associated with avocational performance -Does the patient drive?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: -Document availability of adaptive equipment for ADLs, including both high-  and low-tech,  and mobility devices. Determine whether equipment is appropriate for use at the patient’s current level of function -Document the variety of self-management  strategies used to support performance of daily activities -Physical Self-Maintenance  Scale—questionnaire about ADLs rated on a 5-point  scale of the amount assistance required to perform each activity(10) -Modified Health Assessment Questionnaire (MHAQ)—self-report  of patient’s ability to complete functional activities and/or the amount of assistance required(13)
social and occupational history.living environment: Document the number of stairs, floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A referral to occupational therapy can be made to address the following Decreased functional mobility and ADLs(10) Decreased upper extremity ROM(10) Decreased fine motor dexterity Need for custom-made  splinting or orthotics(10)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Dorsal or wrist ganglions(10) de Quervain’s tenosynovitis(10) Trigger finger (stenosing flexor tenosynovitis)(10) Carpal tunnel syndrome(10)T708512; Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis/Osteoarthrosis: Carpometacarpal Joint of Thumb  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708514; Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis, Hip  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708732; and  Clinical Review…Osteoarthritis, Knee (Nonoperative Management)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708412

other considerations: Older individuals with OA will likely communicate with caregivers how pain negatively impacts their life (i.e., walking ability, mood, sleep, daily activity, and social activity). Some caregivers have reported limited knowledge about OA pain and treatment; therefore, it is important to educate caregivers about causes of OA, common misconceptions, and pain-management  strategies to better support the patient’s lifestyle(25)
treatment summary: Occupational therapists help patients live with OA by improving their ability to perform ADLs in both their home and work environments. They use treatments such as orthoses, education on activity pacing, home/work modifications, and exercises

Authors of a study surveyed 124 therapists (74% occupational therapists and 26% physical therapists) regarding the most commonly used treatments for patients with OA of the CMC joint. Themost commonly reported treatments were a combination of the following:(32) –orthosis prescription (92%) –pain education (78%) –heat (75%) –exercise (74%)

Authors of a study surveyed 52Italian hand therapists (81% physical therapists and 19% occupational therapists) to determine practice patterns for treating OA of the CMC joint(34) –Most therapists provide conservative treatment for OA of the CMC joint. Treatments include custom orthoses, thenar muscle strengthening, closed kinetic chain exercises, passive joint mobilizations, and joint protection instruction

Orthosis/joint protection –Orthotics, hand exercises, and heat and joint protection education might help improve grip strength and function in persons with OA of the hand(18) -Based on a systematic review of the literature on hand therapy interventions for hand OA -Twenty-one  studies reviewed; diagnosis in subjects was OA of the hand, OA, or OA with chronic wrist pain. All studies addressed conservative hand interventions -Data organized and evaluated using the Structured Effectiveness Quality Evaluation Scale (SEQES) and level of evidence (LOE) using the Sackett scale -Moderate evidence supported hand exercises to improve grip strength, hand ROM, and function -Moderate evidence also supported joint protection education, low-level  continuous heat/steam, and use of CMC orthotics to improve hand function and decrease pain -There was moderate evidence indicating that low-level laser therapy was not better than placebo for improving hand function -There was weak evidence to support the use of paraffin

Activity pacing –A tailored activity-pacing  occupational therapy intervention might help improve self-perceived  joint stiffness in adults with knee or hip OA(24) -Based on a study conducted in the United States that included 32 adults with hip and knee OA; participants were randomized to a tailored or general activity-pacing  intervention -Tailored activity pacing was based on symptoms and physical activity over a 5-day  period -Outcomes were measured by self-perceived  joint stiffness at baseline, 4weeks, and 10 weeks -The tailored group experienced decreased stiffness from baseline to 10 weeks –Activity pacing (taking breaks and using a slower pace for activities) in conjunction with individualized feedback might be more effective at reducing pain and fatigue than a general activity-pacing  education program(17) -Based on a study conducted in the United States that included 32 patients aged 50–80  years with symptomatic knee or hip OA not undergoing any treatment; participants were randomized to a tailored activity-pacing  or general activity-pacing group -Data were collected at baseline, after the intervention, and at 10-week  follow-up -All patients wore an accelerometer to measure physical activity, reported symptoms, and activity-pacing  behaviors 6 times per day for a total of 5 days -Tailored group participated in activity-pacing education based on individual progress and symptoms and identified barriers to recommended strategies -Both groups reported decreased pain at 10-week follow-up -Tailored group had less fatigue interference and decreased fatigue severity at 10-week  follow-up

Home/work modifications –Ergonomic assessment and intervention might be more effective than written informational materials to improve function and reduce symptoms in patients with OA and rheumatoid arthritis(20) -Based on an RCT conducted in the United States involving 89 patients with either rheumatoid arthritis or OA -The ergonomic interventions included body mechanics training, home exercises, and workstation modifications. For more information regarding ergonomic assessment and intervention, please see  Clinical Review…Ergonomic Assessment and Intervention  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708456 -Outcome measures included the AIMS 2, Job Satisfaction Survey, and Brief Symptom Inventory Global Severity Index

ROM/strengthening exercises –Authors of a study (N = 252) investigated the relationship between quadriceps and hamstring muscle strength and structural damage, pain, and mobility in patients with OA and symptomatic meniscal tear(31) -Patients with the greatest quadriceps and hamstring strength reported less pain and difficulty with ADLs than those with less quadriceps and hamstring strength -The authors concluded that strengthening of the quadriceps and hamstring muscles may be key in the management of knee OA and symptomatic meniscal tear –Authors of a study investigated longitudinal quadriceps strength changes on performance-based  and self-reported physical function measures over 5 years in patients with or at risk of knee OA(33) -An increase in knee strength over 5 years was associated with improved chair stand ability in women, but not men  -An increase in knee strength over 5 years was not associated with improved walk time or self-reported functional measures in men or women -More targeted task-based  interventions may be needed to improve ADLs - . maintenance or prevention: Home exercise program, including walking, to maintain endurance, strength, and flexibility(19)
Use of joint protection techniques to prevent pain and deformity
Activity pacing to maximize participation in daily activities and prevent extra stress on joints
Environmental modifications to maximize independence with daily activities
